message_1: If P represents the statement "I will study for my math exam" and Q represents the statement "I will pass my math exam," and it is known that "If I study for my math exam, then I will pass it," what is the truth value of the statement "If I do not study for my math exam, then I will not pass it?" (Answer: True)
message_2:
The given statement is "If I study for my math exam, then I will pass it." In logical terms, this can be written as P → Q. 

The statement "If I do not study for my math exam, then I will not pass it" can be written as ¬P → ¬Q. 

To find the truth value of this statement, we can use the contrapositive rule. The contrapositive of a conditional statement P → Q is ¬Q → ¬P. If the original statement is true, then its contrapositive is also true.

In this case, the contrapositive of P → Q is ¬Q → ¬P. Comparing this with the given statement ¬P → ¬Q, we can see that they are equivalent. Since the original statement "If I study for my math exam, then I will pass it" is known to be true, its contrapositive "If I do not study for my math exam, then I will not pass it" is also true.
